column2: Calliope Catesby was in his humours again.
column3: Calliope Catesby was in his humours again.

column2: Ennui was upon him.
column3: Ennui was upon him.

column2: This goodly promontory, the earth--particularly that portion of it known as Quicksand--was to him no more than a pestilent congregation of vapours.
column3: This goodly promontory, the earth-particularly that portion of it known as Quicksand-was to him no more than a pestilent congregation of vapours.

column2: Overtaken by the megrims, the philosopher may seek relief in soliloquy; my lady find solace in tears; the flaccid Easterner scold at the millinery bills of his women folk.
column3: Overtaken by the megrims, the philosopher may seek relief in soliloquy; my lady find solace in tears; the flaccid Easterner scold at the millinery bills of his women folk.

column2: Such recourse was insufficient to the denizens of Quicksand.
column3: Such recourse was insufficient to the denizens of Quicksand.

column2: Calliope, especially, was wont to express his ennui according to his lights.
column3: Calliope, especially, was wont to express his ennui according to his lights.

column2: Over night Calliope had hung out signals of approaching low spirits. He had kicked his own dog on the porch of the Occidental Hotel, and refused to apologise.
column3: Over night Calliope had hung out signals of approaching low spirits. He had kicked his own dog on the porch of the Occidental Hotel, and refused to apologise.

column2: He had become capricious and fault-finding in conversation.
column3: He had become capricious and fault finding in conversation.

column2: While strolling about he reached often for twigs of mesquite and chewed the leaves fiercely.
column3: While strolling about he reached often for twigs of mesquite and chewed the leaves fiercely.

column2: That was always an ominous act.
column3: That was always an ominous act.

column2: Another symptom alarming to those who were familiar with the different stages of his doldrums was his increasing politeness and a tendency to use formal phrases.
column3: Another symptom alarming to those who were familiar with the different stages of his doldrums was his increasing politeness and a tendency to use formal phrases.

column2: A dangerous courtesy marked his manners.
column3: A dangerous courtesy marked his manners.

column2: Later, his smile became crooked, the left side of his mouth slanting upward, and Quicksand got ready to stand from under.
column3: Later, his smile became crooked, the left side of his mouth slanting upward, and Quicksand got ready to stand from under.

column2: At this stage Calliope generally began to drink.
column3: At this stage Calliope generally began to drink.

column2: Finally, about midnight, he was seen going homeward, saluting those whom he met with exaggerated but inoffensive courtesy.
column3: Finally, about midnight, he was seen going homeward, saluting those whom he met with exaggerated but inoffensive courtesy.

column2: More magnanimous than Nero, he would thus give musical warning of the forthcoming municipal upheaval that Quicksand was scheduled to endure.
column3: More magnanimous than Nero, he would thus give musical warning of the forthcoming municipal upheaval that Quicksand was scheduled to endure.

column2: A quiet, amiable man was Calliope Catesby at other times--quiet to indolence, and amiable to worthlessness.
column3: A quiet, amiable man was Calliope Catesby at other times-quiet to indolence, and amiable to worthlessness.

column2: At best he was a loafer and a nuisance; at worst he was the Terror of Quicksand.
column3: At best he was a loafer and a nuisance; at worst he was the Terror of Quicksand.

column2: His ostensible occupation was something subordinate in the real estate line; he drove the beguiled Easterner in buckboards out to look over lots and ranch property.
column3: His ostensible occupation was something subordinate in the real estate line; he drove the beguiled Easterner in buckboards out to look over lots and ranch property.

column2: Originally he came from one of the Gulf States, his lank six feet, slurring rhythm of speech, and sectional idioms giving evidence of his birthplace.
column3: Originally he came from one of the Gulf States, his lank six feet, slurring rhythm of speech, and sectional idioms giving evidence of his birthplace.

column2: Inspired by his own barbarous melodies and the contents of his jug, he was ready primed to gather fresh laurels from the diffident brow of Quicksand.
column3: Inspired by his own barbarous melodies and the contents of his jug, he was ready primed to gather fresh laurels from the diffident brow of Quicksand.

column2: Encircled and criss-crossed with cartridge belts, abundantly garnished with revolvers, and copiously drunk, he poured forth into Quicksand's main street.
column3: Encircled and criss crossed with cartridge belts, abundantly garnished with revolvers, and copiously drunk, he poured forth into Quicksand's main street.

column2: A yellow dog, the personal property of Colonel Swazey, the proprietor of the Occidental, fell feet upward in the dust with one farewell yelp.
column3: A yellow dog, the personal property of Colonel Swazey, the proprietor of the Occidental, fell feet upward in the dust with one farewell yelp.

column2: The artillery was in trim.
column3: The artillery was in trim.

column2: Down the street went Calliope, shooting right and left.
column3: Down the street went Calliope, shooting right and left.

column2: The din was perforated at intervals by the /staccato/ of the Terror's guns, and was drowned periodically by the brazen screech that Quicksand knew so well.
column3: The din was perforated at intervals by the /staccato/ of the Terror's guns, and was drowned periodically by the brazen screech that Quicksand knew so well.

column2: But some four squares farther down lively preparations were being made to minister to Mr. Catesby's love for interchange of compliments and repartee.
column3: But some four squares farther down lively preparations were being made to minister to mr Catesby's love for interchange of compliments and repartee.

column2: The patience of that official, often strained in extending leniency toward the disturber's misdeeds, had been overtaxed.
column3: The patience of that official, often strained in extending leniency toward the disturber's misdeeds, had been overtaxed.

column2: Providing that the lives of the more useful citizens were not recklessly squandered, or too much property needlessly laid waste, the community sentiment was against a too strict enforcement of the law. But Calliope had raised the limit.
column3: Providing that the lives of the more useful citizens were not recklessly squandered, or too much property needlessly laid waste, the community sentiment was against a too strict enforcement of the law. But Calliope had raised the limit.

column2: His outbursts had been too frequent and too violent to come within the classification of a normal and sanitary relaxation of spirit.
column3: His outbursts had been too frequent and too violent to come within the classification of a normal and sanitary relaxation of spirit.

column2: Buck Patterson had been expecting and awaiting in his little ten-by- twelve frame office that preliminary yell announcing that Calliope was feeling blue.
column3: Buck Patterson had been expecting and awaiting in his little ten by twelve frame office that preliminary yell announcing that Calliope was feeling blue.

column2: Gather that fellow in, said Buck Patterson, setting forth the lines of the campaign.
column3: Gather that fellow in, said Buck Patterson, setting forth the lines of the campaign.

column2: Don't have no talk, but shoot as soon as you can get a show.	Don't have no talk, but shoot as soon as you can get a show.
It's up to Calliope to turn up his toes this time, I reckon.
column3: It's up to Calliope to turn up his toes this time, I reckon.

column2: Go to him all spraddled out, boys.
column3: Go to him all spraddled out, boys.

column2: Buck Patterson, tall, muscular, and solemn-faced, with his bright "City Marshal" badge shining on the breast of his blue flannel shirt, gave his posse directions for the onslaught upon Calliope.
column3: Buck Patterson, tall, muscular, and solemn faced, with his bright "City Marshal" badge shining on the breast of his blue flannel shirt, gave his posse directions for the onslaught upon Calliope.

column2: The plan was to accomplish the downfall of the Quicksand Terror without loss to the attacking party, if possible.
column3: The plan was to accomplish the downfall of the Quicksand Terror without loss to the attacking party, if possible.

column2: The splenetic Calliope, unconscious of retributive plots, was steaming down the channel, cannonading on either side, when he suddenly became aware of breakers ahead.
column3: The splenetic Calliope, unconscious of retributive plots, was steaming down the channel, cannonading on either side, when he suddenly became aware of breakers ahead.

column2: The city marshal and one of the deputies rose up behind some dry-goods boxes half a square to the front and opened fire.
column3: The city marshal and one of the deputies rose up behind some dry goods boxes half a square to the front and opened fire.

column2: At the same time the rest of the posse, divided, shelled him from two side streets up which they were cautiously manoeuvring from a well-executed detour.
column3: At the same time the rest of the posse, divided, shelled him from two side streets up which they were cautiously manoeuvring from a well executed detour.

column2: Feeling braced up by this unexpected tonic to his spiritual depression, Calliope executed a fortissimo note from his upper register, and returned the fire like an echo.
column3: Feeling braced up by this unexpected tonic to his spiritual depression, Calliope executed a fortissimo note from his upper register, and returned the fire like an echo.

column2: Choosing with a rapid eye the street from which the weakest and least accurate fire had come, he invaded it at a double-quick, abandoning the unprotected middle of the street.
column3: Choosing with a rapid eye the street from which the weakest and least accurate fire had come, he invaded it at a double quick, abandoning the unprotected middle of the street.

column2: With rare cunning the opposing force in that direction--one of the deputies and two of the valorous volunteers-- waited, concealed by beer barrels, until Calliope had passed their retreat, and then peppered him from the rear.
column3: With rare cunning the opposing force in that direction-one of the deputies and two of the valorous volunteers- waited, concealed by beer barrels, until Calliope had passed their retreat, and then peppered him from the rear.

column2: His eye fell upon a structure that seemed to hold out this promise, providing he could reach it.
column3: His eye fell upon a structure that seemed to hold out this promise, providing he could reach it.

column2: Not far away was the little railroad station, its building a strong box house, ten by twenty feet, resting upon a platform four feet above ground.
column3: Not far away was the little railroad station, its building a strong box house, ten by twenty feet, resting upon a platform four feet above ground.

column2: Windows were in each of its walls.
column3: Windows were in each of its walls.

column2: Something like a fort it might become to a man thus sorely pressed by superior numbers.
column3: Something like a fort it might become to a man thus sorely pressed by superior numbers.

column2: Calliope made a bold and rapid spurt for it, the marshal's crowd "smoking" him as he ran.
column3: Calliope made a bold and rapid spurt for it, the marshal's crowd "smoking" him as he ran.

column2: He reached the haven in safety, the station agent leaving the building by a window, like a flying squirrel, as the garrison entered the door.
column3: He reached the haven in safety, the station agent leaving the building by a window, like a flying squirrel, as the garrison entered the door.

column2: In the station was an unterrified desperado who was an excellent shot and carried an abundance of ammunition.
column3: In the station was an unterrified desperado who was an excellent shot and carried an abundance of ammunition.

column2: The city marshal was resolved.
column3: The city marshal was resolved.

column2: He had decided that Calliope Catesby should no more wake the echoes of Quicksand with his strident whoop. He had so announced.
column3: He had decided that Calliope Catesby should no more wake the echoes of Quicksand with his strident whoop. He had so announced.

column2: It played bad tunes.
column3: It played bad tunes.

column2: Standing near was a hand truck used in the manipulation of small freight.
column3: Standing near was a hand truck used in the manipulation of small freight.

column2: It stood by a shed full of sacked wool, a consignment from one of the sheep ranches.
column3: It stood by a shed full of sacked wool, a consignment from one of the sheep ranches.

column2: On this truck the marshal and his men piled three heavy sacks of wool.
column3: On this truck the marshal and his men piled three heavy sacks of wool.

column2: The posse, scattering broadly, stood ready to nip the besieged in case he should show himself in an effort to repel the juggernaut of justice that was creeping upon him.
column3: The posse, scattering broadly, stood ready to nip the besieged in case he should show himself in an effort to repel the juggernaut of justice that was creeping upon him.

column2: Only once did Calliope make demonstration.
column3: Only once did Calliope make demonstration.

column2: He fired from a window, and some tufts of wool spurted from the marshal's trustworthy bulwark.
column3: He fired from a window, and some tufts of wool spurted from the marshal's trustworthy bulwark.

column2: The return shots from the posse pattered against the window frame of the fort.
column3: The return shots from the posse pattered against the window frame of the fort.

column2: No loss resulted on either side.
column3: No loss resulted on either side.

column2: The marshal was too deeply engrossed in steering his protected battleship to be aware of the approach of the morning train until he was within a few feet of the platform.
column3: The marshal was too deeply engrossed in steering his protected battleship to be aware of the approach of the morning train until he was within a few feet of the platform.

column2: He had only to step out the other door, mount the train, and away.
column3: He had only to step out the other door, mount the train, and away.

column2: The members of the posse heard one shot fired inside, and then there was silence.
column3: The members of the posse heard one shot fired inside, and then there was silence.

column2: After a blank space he again could see and hear and feel and think.
column3: After a blank space he again could see and hear and feel and think.

column2: A tall man with a perplexed countenance, wearing a big badge with "City Marshal" engraved upon it, stood over him.
column3: A tall man with a perplexed countenance, wearing a big badge with "City Marshal" engraved upon it, stood over him.

column2: A little old woman in black, with a wrinkled face and sparkling black eyes, was holding a wet handkerchief against one of his temples.
column3: A little old woman in black, with a wrinkled face and sparkling black eyes, was holding a wet handkerchief against one of his temples.

column2: He was trying to get these facts fixed in his mind and connected with past events, when the old woman began to talk.
column3: He was trying to get these facts fixed in his mind and connected with past events, when the old woman began to talk.

column2: There now, great, big, strong man!	There now, great, big, strong man!
You don't know me, I reckon, and 'tain't surprisin' that you shouldn't.
column3: You don't know me, I reckon, and 'tain't surprisin' that you shouldn't.

column2: This is my son, sir."
column3: This is my son, sir."

column2: Half turning, the old woman looked up at the standing man, her worn face lighting with a proud and wonderful smile.
column3: Half turning, the old woman looked up at the standing man, her worn face lighting with a proud and wonderful smile.

column2: She reached out one veined and calloused hand and took one of her son's.
column3: She reached out one veined and calloused hand and took one of her son's.

column2: One of my nephews, Elkanah Price, he's a conductor on one of them railroads and he got me a pass to come out here.
column3: One of my nephews, Elkanah Price, he's a conductor on one of them railroads and he got me a pass to come out here.

column2: I can stay a whole week on it, and then it'll take me back again.
column3: I can stay a whole week on it, and then it'll take me back again.

column2: I reckon he thought his old mother'd be skeered about the danger he was in.
column3: I reckon he thought his old mother'd be skeered about the danger he was in.

column2: But, laws!
column3: But, laws!

column2: He met me at the door, and squeezes me 'most to death.
column3: He met me at the door, and squeezes me 'most to death.

column2: I think I'll sit up now, said the concussion patient.
column3: I think I'll sit up now, said the concussion patient.

column2: I'm feeling pretty fair by this time.
column3: I'm feeling pretty fair by this time.

column2: He sat, somewhat weakly yet, leaning against the wall.
column3: He sat, somewhat weakly yet, leaning against the wall.

column2: He was a rugged man, big-boned and straight.
column3: He was a rugged man, big boned and straight.

column2: Don't you take it as meddlesome fer an old woman with a son as big as you to talk about it.
column3: Don't you take it as meddlesome fer an old woman with a son as big as you to talk about it.

column2: A officer has got to take up for the law--it's his duty--and them that acts bad and lives wrong has to suffer.
column3: A officer has got to take up for the law-it's his duty-and them that acts bad and lives wrong has to suffer.

column2: Don't blame my son any, sir--'tain't his fault.
column3: Don't blame my son any, sir-'tain't his fault.

column2: He's always been a good boy--good when he was growin' up, and kind and 'bedient and well-behaved.
column3: He's always been a good boy-good when he was growin' up, and kind and 'bedient and well behaved.

column2: Won't you let me advise you, sir, not to do so no more?
column3: Won't you let me advise you, sir, not to do so no more?

column2: Be a good man, and leave liquor alone and live peaceably and goodly.
column3: Be a good man, and leave liquor alone and live peaceably and goodly.

column2: The black-mitted hand of the old pleader gently touched the breast of the man she addressed.
column3: The black mitted hand of the old pleader gently touched the breast of the man she addressed.

column2: What does the marshal say? he asked.
column3: What does the marshal say? he asked.

column2: Suppose the marshal speaks up and says if the talk's all right?"
column3: Suppose the marshal speaks up and says if the talk's all right?"

column2: He fingered the badge on his breast for a moment, and then he put an arm around the old woman and drew her close to him.
column3: He fingered the badge on his breast for a moment, and then he put an arm around the old woman and drew her close to him.

column2: I'll drop the tanglefoot and the gun play, and won't play hoss no more.
column3: I'll drop the tanglefoot and the gun play, and won't play hoss no more.

column2: I'll be a good citizen and go to work and quit my foolishness.
column3: I'll be a good citizen and go to work and quit my foolishness.

column2: So help me God!' That's what I'd say to you if you was marshal and I was in your place."
column3: So help me God!' That's what I'd say to you if you was marshal and I was in your place."

column2: Hear my son talkin', said the old woman softly.
column3: Hear my son talkin', said the old woman softly.

column2: Hear him, sir.	Hear him, sir.
You promise to be good and he won't do you no harm.
column3: You promise to be good and he won't do you no harm.

column2: I wouldn't have nothin' happen to them jars for a red apple."
column3: I wouldn't have nothin' happen to them jars for a red apple."

column2: I seen her through the window a-comin' in.
column3: I seen her through the window a comin' in.

column2: The idea struck me sudden, and I just took your badge off and fastened it onto myself, and I fastened my reputation onto you.
column3: The idea struck me sudden, and I just took your badge off and fastened it onto myself, and I fastened my reputation onto you.

column2: You can take your badge back now, Buck."
column3: You can take your badge back now, Buck."

column2: Easy there! said Buck Patterson.
column3: Easy there! said Buck Patterson.

column2: You keep that badge right where it is, Calliope Catesby.	You keep that badge right where it is, Calliope Catesby.
Don't you dare to take it off till the day your mother leaves this town.
column3: Don't you dare to take it off till the day your mother leaves this town.

column2: Shut up, said Buck.
